lead_paragraph: Oil bulls are once again kicking up dust. The intensifying struggle to lift output, they say, will collide with the insatiable thirst of an expanding Asia to push oil above $100 a barrel. In fact, the cost of crude may be held down as demand growth is cut by half as producers from Russia to Africa via Brazil ramp up supply.

abstract: The government could sue BP over the Gulf of Mexico oil spill as soon as Wednesday, joining the sprawling litigation that already involves some 23,000 plaintiffs, The Wall Street Journal reported.
snippet: The government could sue BP over the Gulf of Mexico oil spill as soon as Wednesday, joining the sprawling litigation that already involves some 23,000 plaintiffs, The Wall Street Journal reported.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Justice could sue BP over the Gulf of Mexico oil spill as soon as Wednesday, joining the sprawling federal litigation that already involves some 23,000 plaintiffs, The Wall Street Journal reported on Tuesday. Judge Carl J. Barbier, who is running the centralized litigation from New Orleans, issued an order in October that all “master complaints” should be filed by Dec. 15. Stephen J. Herman, a leader of the group of plaintiffs’ lawyers in the case, said that he had not heard that the government was preparing to join the litigation, but added, “It was inevitable that they were going to file suit.”

abstract: The current situation demands an “all of the above” strategy when it comes to diversifying the nation’s energy portfolio, two officials write.
snippet: The current situation demands an “all of the above” strategy when it comes to diversifying the nation’s energy portfolio, two officials write.
lead_paragraph: In an essay co-authored with Spencer Abraham, energy secretary under President George W. Bush, Fred Upton of Michigan, the leading Republican candidate for chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee in next year’s Congress, calls for opening the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska to oil drilling, a massive increase in domestic deepwater oil production and a rapid expansion of nuclear power. Yet “oil and nuclear are not the only energy sources we need more of,” the two write. “The current situation demands an ‘all of the above’ strategy — diversifying our energy portfolio and pushing development of our own natural resources. That means not just more oil and nuclear, but more coal, natural gas and renewables. Sooner rather than later.” [Politico]

lead_paragraph: Kenneth Feinberg is making solid progress as the administrator of BP’s $20 billion compensation fund for victims of the gulf oil spill. Tuesday was the deadline for filing claims for emergency payments, equal to six months of lost income. Mr. Feinberg estimates that he has handed out more than $2.2 billion to some 150,000 individuals and businesses from a total of more than 400,000 claims. This is a great improvement over the stingy BP operation he replaced.

But a deal signed this month would transform these placid waters into a seaport for giant cargo ships. Cashew nut groves and rice fields would be plowed under and replaced with a warren of factories, refineries and an expansive coal-burning power plant.

abstract: There may not be time for a breakthrough on energy and environmental issues in Congress’s remaining weeks, but it is still possible to pass some important legislation.
snippet: There may not be time for a breakthrough on energy and environmental issues in Congress’s remaining weeks, but it is still possible to pass some important legislation.
lead_paragraph: This Congress’s record on energy and environmental issues is shameful. The Senate, paralyzed by Republican opposition and indifferent Democratic leadership, could not muster the 60 votes to pass legislation to reduce carbon emissions. It even failed to respond to the gulf oil spill.

headline.main: Energy and the Lame Duck
headline.print_headline: Energy and the Lame Duck

lead_paragraph: Government and the oil industry were both thoroughly unprepared for a deepwater blowout and oil spill like the one that occurred this year in the gulf, leading to significant delays in capping the well and major environmental damage, the staff of the presidential spill commission concluded in two reports published on Monday.

snippet: A Louisiana senator stops blocking an appointment after Interior Secretary Ken Salazar pledges to help expedite offshore drillling permits.
lead_paragraph: Senator Mary Landrieu, Demcrat of Louisiana,  dropped her hold on Jack Lew, President Obama’s nominee for director of the Office of Management and Budget, on Thursday evening. Mr. Lew was confirmed by the Senate immediately after the hold was relinquished. Ms. Landrieu had blocked the nomination for nearly two months to pressure over concerns that drilling permits were not being issued quickly enough in the aftermath of the BP oil spill. [Politics Daily]

headline.main: On Our Radar: Landrieu Drops Hold on Budget Nominee

lead_paragraph: A few days ago, I had breakfast with Kenneth R. Feinberg, the former pay czar and 9/11 fund administrator, who is now grappling with one of the most difficult assignments of his career: doling out as much as $20 billion of BP’s cash to residents of the Gulf Coast who suffered as a result of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill.

headline.main: Justice for Spill Victims, Like It or Not

lead_paragraph: What is being billed as the largest biodiesel plant in the world started production this week in Singapore. Operated by Neste Oil, the plant has the capacity to produce 800,000 metric tons of fuel per year. The fuel is made from vegetable oils or a combination of oils and waste animal fat sourced from the food industry. [Marketwatch]

headline.main: On Our Radar: World’s Largest Biodiesel Plant Opens in Singapore

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Inadequate training and supervision of key personnel aboard the Deepwater Horizon drilling rig and a lack of focus on safety were among the factors that contributed to the explosion that killed 11 workers and sent millions of barrels of oil gushing into the Gulf of Mexico, according to a preliminary report released Wednesday by a team of scientific experts.

headline.print_headline: Spill Report Faults BP and Contractors

snippet: A report commissioned by Interior Secretary Ken Salazar found a lack of “management discipline” on the Deepwater Horizon.
lead_paragraph: A breakdown in BP’s management system and a failure to strongly consider risk contributed to the Deepwater Horizon rig explosion that killed 11 workers and flooded the Gulf of Mexico with oil, a preliminary report by a team of scientific experts found on Tuesday.

headline.main: BP and Minerals Agency Faulted in Gulf Spill
headline.print_headline: Report Faults BP Management and U.S. Agency in Spill

[Financial Times]

headline.main: On Our Radar: Diesel Shortage Hits China

abstract: Oil and gas industry experts say that despite several major accidents this year, pipelines are getting safer as technology improves.
snippet: Oil and gas industry experts say that despite several major accidents this year, pipelines are getting safer as technology improves.
lead_paragraph: UNDERGROUND oil and gas pipelines are an often-forgotten part of the nation’s energy infrastructure  until problems occur. This year has seen a spate of attention-getting accidents. In San Bruno, Calif., a gas pipeline exploded in a residential area in September, killing eight people. In Texas, two gas pipeline accidents within a day of each other in June killed three people. In Michigan, an oil pipeline ruptured this summer, spilling hundreds of thousands of gallons of oil into a river.

headline.main: Some Exceptions to the Rule, but Pipelines Are Safer
headline.print_headline: Some Exceptions to the Rule, but Pipelines Are Safer

abstract: A presidential commission is beginning to confirm that the gulf oil spill was the result of bad decisions by companies with dangerously skewed priorities.
snippet: A presidential commission is beginning to confirm that the gulf oil spill was the result of bad decisions by companies with dangerously skewed priorities.
lead_paragraph: Though its final report is two months away, the presidential commission investigating the gulf oil spill is beginning to confirm what we already suspected and feared. The April blowout on the Deepwater Horizon was not some unfortunate occurrence. It was the result of a series of bad decisions by companies less concerned about safety than about finishing a project that was over budget and 38 days behind schedule.

headline.main: A Culture of Carelessness
headline.print_headline: A Culture of Carelessness

abstract: Senators on the Environment and Public Works Committee accused the White House of editing a report on the BP spill for political ends.
snippet: Senators on the Environment and Public Works Committee accused the White House of editing a report on the BP spill for political ends.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Three Republican senators demanded Friday that the White House explain last-minute editing changes to an Interior Department report on the BP oil spill that falsely implied that a group of independent experts had endorsed a political decision to temporarily halt all deepwater oil drilling.

headline.main: 3 Republicans Say Report on Spill Was Manipulated
headline.print_headline: 3 Republicans Say Report On Spill Was Manipulated

snippet: An inspector general says staff members edited a report in a way that made it seem as though scientists had recommended a deepwater drilling moratorium. They had not.
lead_paragraph: Some 11th-hour White House fiddling with an Interior Department report on offshore drilling safety wrongly implied that engineering experts had endorsed a political decision to impose a six-month ban on deepwater drilling, the department’s inspector general concluded in a finding made public this week.

headline.main: White House Editing Caused Drilling Ban Dispute

lead_paragraph: If your gasoline and electricity bills go up in the years to come, and you want to blame someone other than yourself, a new report by the International Energy Agency has some ammunition for you.

abstract: What would happen if gasoline prices in the United States rose to European levels?
snippet: What would happen if gasoline prices in the United States rose to European levels?
lead_paragraph: When I dropped off a rental car recently in New York City after visiting my daughter at her college’s parents weekend, I suffered a severe case of sticker shock. I had been cursing myself for forgetting to refuel the midsize car in New Jersey before re-entering New York. Now I would be stuck paying New York gas prices.

headline.main: In the U.S., Sticker Shock in Reverse

snippet: Energy use in China is predicted to surge 75 percent by 2035, and the country is poised to drive development of renewable power.
lead_paragraph: China’s push for rapid economic development will dominate global energy markets and be the single biggest force in spurring higher oil prices and carbon emissions linked to climate change over the next quarter-century, the International Energy Agency reported on Tuesday.

headline.print_headline: In Global Forecast, China Looms Large as Energy User and Maker of Green Power

headline.print_headline: Investigator Finds No Evidence That BP Took Shortcuts to Save Money

snippet: Charles Fisher, the chief scientist on an expedition studying  coral colonies in the Gulf of Mexico,  expected to see some subtle effects from the oil spill. Instead, he found an ecosystem in collapse.
lead_paragraph: Early on in the BP oil spill, I interviewed some marine biologists who had spent nearly a decade charting a series of deepwater coral reefs in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline.main: Coral Die-Off Took Scientist by Surprise

snippet: The large swaths of darkened coral were almost certainly dying from exposure to toxins, scientists said.
lead_paragraph: A survey of the seafloor near BP’s blown-out well in the Gulf of Mexico has turned up dead and dying coral reefs that were probably damaged by the oil spill, scientists said Friday.

headline.main: Dead Coral Found Near Site of Oil Spill
headline.print_headline: Dead Coral Found in Gulf, With Oil the Main Suspect

snippet: Gov. Bobby Jindal said Louisiana would scale back and alter a berm-building project, constructing some barrier islands instead.
lead_paragraph: Louisiana is scaling back and altering a project to construct sand berms along its coast to block and capture oil from the BP spill, the state’s governor, Bobby Jindal, said this week.

headline.print_headline: Focus Changes For Louisiana In Oil Cleanup

snippet: Eager to begin its stalled plan to drill in the Alaskan Arctic, the oil company is starting a lobbying campaign.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  Eager to win approval for its stalled plan to drill for oil in the Alaskan Arctic, Royal Dutch Shell is beginning a public lobbying campaign, including national advertising, on Monday. As part of the effort, the giant oil company is promising to make unprecedented preparations to prevent the kind of disaster that polluted the Gulf of Mexico earlier this year.

headline.main: Shell Presses for Drilling in Arctic
headline.print_headline: Shell Presses For Drilling In Arctic

abstract: Some $100 million intended for the construction of sand berms to block oil along the gulf coast will be repurposed for coastal restoration.
snippet: Some $100 million intended for the construction of sand berms to block oil along the gulf coast will be repurposed for coastal restoration.
lead_paragraph: In a story in late October, I reported on the continuing effort by Louisiana to build sand berms in the Gulf of Mexico to block and capture oil from the BP spill. Back in June, BP ponied up $360 million for the berms, of which roughly $140 million was left.

headline.main: Louisiana Rethinks Its Sand Berms

abstract: BP employees gave an “F-rank” to 148 pipelines in the oil giant’s Alaska network because of corrosion and other maintenance problems, according to a report by ProPublica.
snippet: BP employees gave an “F-rank” to 148 pipelines in the oil giant’s Alaska network because of corrosion and other maintenance problems, according to a report by ProPublica.
lead_paragraph: Is there another BP disaster waiting to happen, this time in Alaska?

abstract: Idaho’s supreme court said that neither it, nor a lower court, had jurisdiction in a case brought over state permits allowing oil companies to move big equipment along a historic two-lane highway.
snippet: Idaho’s supreme court said that neither it, nor a lower court, had jurisdiction in a case brought over state permits allowing oil companies to move big equipment along a historic two-lane highway.
lead_paragraph: Efforts to block shipments of giant oil processing equipment along a historic stretch of Highway 12 in Idaho, which I wrote about two weeks ago, were dealt a blow by the state Supreme Court there on Monday — or so it would seem.

headline.main: Idaho Court Punts on Oil Shipments

abstract: Trial lawyers like Tony Buzbee got rich putting the screws to corporate America. But in the wave of gulf-spill litigation, they’re struggling to not get cut out of the action.
snippet: Trial lawyers like Tony Buzbee got rich putting the screws to corporate America. But in the wave of gulf-spill litigation, they’re struggling to not get cut out of the action.
lead_paragraph: It was a little past 9 on a scorching July morning in South Texas, and Tony Buzbee was gunning down the Gulf Freeway outside Houston in his cherry red Ferrari 612 Scaglietti (license plate BUZB 8) on his way to a court hearing in Galveston. Buzbee’s right hand was occupied with one of his ever-present La Gloria Cubana cigars, while his left stayed in intermittent contact with the wheel as he recounted how he destroyed an insurance company’s expert witness in a recent deposition. So total was the demolition, in Buzbee’s telling, that the witness retired on the spot from any future trial work. “I basically made him admit that his entire compensation model was” fouled up, Buzbee said with undisguised relish, as well as the blunt profanity that is a hallmark of his conversations.

headline.main: The Other Oil Cleanup
headline.print_headline: Slick on Slick

abstract: The company set aside an additional $7.7 billion for expenses related to the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.
snippet: The company set aside an additional $7.7 billion for expenses related to the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.
lead_paragraph: LONDON  BP said Tuesday that it had set aside an additional $7.7 billion for expenses related to the Gulf of Mexico oil spill, mainly because of a delay in the completion of the relief well that permanently sealed the leak.

headline.main: BP Profit Down on Oil Spill Charges
headline.print_headline: BP’s Profit Declines On Oil Spill Charges

abstract: The ability to replace equity with debt has come back with a vengeance.
snippet: The ability to replace equity with debt has come back with a vengeance.
lead_paragraph: Buyout barons are paying themselves on the back of the market’s short memory. Dividend recapitalizations are on pace to exceed the volume in 2007. Dunkin’ Brands and Getty Images illustrate the latest efforts by private equity firms to get ahead of potential changes to American tax laws. But in their zealous quest for Treasury-topping returns, investors seem to have forgotten recent lessons.

headline.main: Investors Forget Lending Lessons
headline.print_headline: Investors Forget Lending Lessons

lead_paragraph: SOUTHWEST PASS, La.  A couple of weeks ago, enormous orange-brownish strings of something were seen floating out here in the open water near the mouth of the Mississippi.

headline.print_headline: Cleanup and Questions Continue

lead_paragraph: Excerpts from the final statement by the former chairman of the Yukos oil company at the conclusion on Monday of his 20-month trial in Moscow on charges of embezzling oil from his own company. Translated by Stephan Lang.

abstract: Of 1,735 tissue samples analyzed, only 13 showed trace amounts of  oil dispersant residue, in concentrations well below safety thresholds established by federal agencies, officials say.
snippet: Of 1,735 tissue samples analyzed, only 13 showed trace amounts of  oil dispersant residue, in concentrations well below safety thresholds established by federal agencies, officials say.
lead_paragraph: Extensive testing of Gulf of Mexico seafood by federal scientists has found only minute traces of the dispersant Corexit, which was used to break up oil from the BP spill, officials say. About 1.8 million gallons of dispersant were applied to the waters’ surface and at the wellhead, nearly a mile undersea.

headline.main: Gulf Seafood Is Safe, Officials Say

abstract: The walkouts have caused gasoline shortages across the country and cost France’s oil industry several hundreds of millions of dollars.
snippet: The walkouts have caused gasoline shortages across the country and cost France’s oil industry several hundreds of millions of dollars.
lead_paragraph: Workers voted Friday to end walkouts Friday at major French oil terminals and six of the country’s 12 refineries, after as many as 33 consecutive days on strike. The walkouts, most of which were in protest of President Nicolas Sarkozy’s proposed increase in the national retirement age, have caused gasoline shortages across the country and cost France’s oil industry several hundreds of millions of dollars, according to the French Union of Petroleum Industries. Gasoline shortages were expected to all but end this weekend, officials said, and refining operations were to begin again in the coming days. France’s lower house of Parliament gave final approval to the pension reform on Wednesday, and it is expected to become law in mid-November.

headline.main: France: Oil Workers Vote to End Their Walkouts
headline.print_headline: France: Oil Workers Vote To End Their Walkouts; Gas Shortages Are Expected To End Quickly

abstract: The company issued a statement on Thursday after a panel said a failed cement job on the well had contributed to the blowout.
snippet: The company issued a statement on Thursday after a panel said a failed cement job on the well had contributed to the blowout.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Halliburton, whose failed cement job on the BP well in the Gulf of Mexico was identified as a contributing factor to the deadly blowout by a presidential investigative panel on Thursday, is defending its work and assigning the blame for the accident to BP.

headline.main: Halliburton Rejects Blame for BP Cement Job
headline.print_headline: Halliburton Rejects Blame for BP Cement Job

abstract: A new report on the fatal explosion involving the Macondo well is another reminder that the drilling industry must be tightly regulated.
snippet: A new report on the fatal explosion involving the Macondo well is another reminder that the drilling industry must be tightly regulated.
lead_paragraph: We have known for some time that a flaw in the cement used on BP’s Macondo well contributed to the disastrous April 20 explosion in the Gulf of Mexico. What we did not know, until now, was that both BP and Halliburton, the company BP hired to cement the well, appear to have been aware that the mixture was prone to failure  and went ahead anyway.

headline.main: The Latest Gulf Outrage
headline.print_headline: The Latest Gulf Outrage

snippet: Royal Dutch Shell also reported strong results, following a ConocoPhillips report on Wednesday that its quarterly income had nearly doubled.

headline.main: Exxon Profit Soars 55% as Oil Prices Rebound
headline.print_headline: Exxon Profit Soars 55% As Oil Prices Rebound

lead_paragraph: The six-month anniversary of the BP oil spill passed quietly last week. The well has been capped, and commerce in the Gulf of Mexico is slowly reviving. Much important work still lies ahead  figuring out how much oil is still out there, cleaning it up, measuring the damage to marine life, compensating victims. And Congress needs to pass an oil-spill bill that will reduce the chances of another drilling debacle.

abstract: The oil company is going forward with a $7.5 billion project to develop two giant deepwater fields in the gulf that could yield the equivalent of what the world consumes in oil every five days.
snippet: The oil company is going forward with a $7.5 billion project to develop two giant deepwater fields in the gulf that could yield the equivalent of what the world consumes in oil every five days.
lead_paragraph: Just nine days after the Obama Administration lifted the deepwater drilling moratorium, Chevron announced on Thursday that it was going forward with a $7.5 billion project to develop two giant deepwater fields in the gulf. The Jack and St. Malo fields hold in excess of 500 million barrels of recoverable hydrocarbons, the company said. That’s roughly equal to the world’s oil consumption in about five days — nothing to sneeze at.

headline.main: For Chevron, 2 Giant Gulf Drilling Ventures

abstract: How a vast and well-organized group of amateur enthusiasts helped save their beloved creatures.
snippet: How a vast and well-organized group of amateur enthusiasts helped save their beloved creatures.
lead_paragraph: Loggerhead nesting season started this year, as usual, in May. Across the northeastern coast of the Gulf of Mexico, female sea turtles began plodding out of the water and up the beach, each burying a clutch of a hundred or more leathery eggs beneath the sand. The eggs incubate for about 60 days. Then a throng of tiny black loggerhead hatchlings, each only about two inches long, frantically boils out of the ground, all paddling clumsily with their outsize, winglike flippers. They scuttle down the beach en masse, capitalizing on a one-time frenzy of energy to rush into the water and push past the breakers into offshore currents. Once they make it there — if they make it there — they typically find their way onto mats of seaweed called sargassum. The hatchlings will drift passively around the ocean on this sargassum for the first several years of their lives, like children inner-tubing in a swimming pool. It’s a life raft from which, conveniently, they can also pluck snacks. Many turtles wind up gliding around the Florida peninsula and floating as far out as the Azores during a developmental stage biologists call “the lost years.”

headline.main: The BP-Spill Baby-Turtle Brigade
headline.print_headline: Turtle People

abstract: BP said Monday that it resumed drilling of a relief well that is intended to put the final plug in its stricken well in the Gulf of Mexico.
snippet: BP said Monday that it resumed drilling of a relief well that is intended to put the final plug in its stricken well in the Gulf of Mexico.
lead_paragraph: BP said Monday that it resumed drilling of a relief well that is intended to put the final plug in its stricken well in the Gulf of Mexico. The company said that the crew of the Development Driller III rig began drilling again after technicians installed a device called a lockdown sleeve at the top of the stricken well on the seabed. The sleeve will keep a seal in place, preventing further leakage of oil and gas, if pressure inside the well increases during the final plugging operation. No appreciable amount of oil or gas has leaked for nearly two months. Company officials have said it will take about four days for the relief well to intercept the stricken well. After that, the final plugging operation, which will involve pumping mud and cement into the stricken well, should take about a week.

lead_paragraph: Eike Batista may soon be adding billions to his bank balance. That looks like a bargain against the $8.51 a barrel the government is extracting from Petrobras for deepwater crude. lead_paragraph: Last Thursday’s fire on a shallow-water oil production platform in the Gulf of Mexico claimed no lives and has caused no environmental damage. abstract: High seas have forced further delays in BP’s efforts to permanently plug the well that leaked millions of barrels of oil into the Gulf of Mexico.

lead_paragraph: High seas have forced further delays in BP’s efforts to permanently plug the well that leaked millions of barrels of oil into the Gulf of Mexico. Thad W. Allen, the retired Coast Guard admiral who is leading the government’s response effort, said in a conference call on Monday that waves six to eight feet high had prevented crews from replacing equipment on the seabed in preparation for the final plugging of the well through a relief well. The removal of a capping stack, which was installed atop the well last month, and the original damaged blowout preventer will eventually be replaced by another blowout preventer that can manage pressure changes resulting from the final plugging procedure. Admiral Allen said the bad weather would probably delay work for two to three days, pushing the completion of the relief well to the end of next week.

abstract: BP engineers and government scientists are evaluating alternatives for proceeding with a relief well that is intended to put the final plug in the Macondo well in the Gulf of Mexico.
snippet: BP engineers and government scientists are evaluating alternatives for proceeding with a relief well that is intended to put the final plug in the Macondo well in the Gulf of Mexico.
lead_paragraph: BP engineers and government scientists are evaluating alternatives for proceeding with a relief well that is intended to put the final plug in the Macondo well in the Gulf of Mexico, the leader of the federal response to the disaster said Wednesday in Cedar Key. The official, Thad W. Allen, a retired Coast Guard admiral, said there was no timetable for completing the relief well. But he said that in the meantime, BP was preparing to replace the damaged blowout preventer on the Macondo well with a new one, which could be used to help manage pressure within the well. BP has estimated that there are about 1,000 barrels of oil in the Macondo well, trapped between seals at the top and cement at the bottom that was pumped in this month. One concern is that using the relief well to pump more cement into the Macondo well could raise the pressure within that well, damage the seals and, potentially, result in a spill of the oil.

headline.print_headline: Oil Plume Is Not Breaking Down Fast, Study Says

byline.original: By Justin Gillis and John Collins Rudolf

abstract: Enormous deposits of natural gas have been detected off Israel’s coast, raising the possibility of great benefits but also big challenges.
snippet: Enormous deposits of natural gas have been detected off Israel’s coast, raising the possibility of great benefits but also big challenges.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM  For decades, Israelis have taken perverse pride in what they lacked  oil and gas deposits. Few countries had looked so hard with so little result. Obliged to live off their wits, Israelis turned their country into a high-tech haven.

headline.main: Natural Gas Deposits Improve Israel’s Energy Outlook
headline.print_headline: For Israelis, New Hopes On Energy

abstract: P.R. missteps at BP, Toyota and Goldman Sachs raise a question: Are some crises impossible to spin?
snippet: P.R. missteps at BP, Toyota and Goldman Sachs raise a question: Are some crises impossible to spin?
lead_paragraph: WHOEVER suggested that all publicity is good publicity clearly never envisioned the wave of catastrophe engulfing high-profile corporations over the last year, laying waste to some of the most meticulously tailored reputations on earth.

headline.main: In Case of Emergency: What Not to Do
headline.print_headline: In Case Of Emergency: What Not To Do

abstract: BP will delay the final sealing of its stricken well while it replaces some equipment on the well that led to its failure in April.
snippet: BP will delay the final sealing of its stricken well while it replaces some equipment on the well that led to its failure in April.
lead_paragraph: The final sealing of BP’s stricken well in the Gulf of Mexico will be delayed until after Labor Day, officials said on Thursday, so that the company can replace equipment that contributed to the well’s failure.

headline.main: Well to Be Sealed After Labor Day
headline.print_headline: Maneuver Will Delay Final ‘Kill’ Of Gulf Well

byline.original: By Henry Fountain and John M. Broder

abstract: SAC Capital Advisors, the hedge fund firm run by the billionaire Steven A. Cohen, increased its stakes in Exxon Mobil and BP during the second quarter.
snippet: SAC Capital Advisors, the hedge fund firm run by the billionaire Steven A. Cohen, increased its stakes in Exxon Mobil and BP during the second quarter.
lead_paragraph: Carl C. Icahn was certainly not alone on Monday in disclosing his growing interest in the oil industry. Steven A. Cohen, left, the prominent hedge fund manager, has also raised his bets on oil companies, including Exxon Mobil and BP — even though the latter has taken a severe hit to its finances and reputation because of the oil disaster in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline.main: Cohen Moves Deeper Into Oil

abstract: Vedanta Resources sees the move as a way to increase domestic oil production.
snippet: Vedanta Resources sees the move as a way to increase domestic oil production.
lead_paragraph: Vedanta Resources, a mining company based in Britain, said Monday that it would buy a stake in an Indian energy company for $9.6 billion in a move intended to bolster India’s domestic oil production.

headline.main: British Mining Company Buying Stake in Oil Business in India
headline.print_headline: British Mining Company Buying Stake in Oil Business in India

abstract: While some progress has been made on the oil spill crisis in the Gulf of Mexico, the restoration is far from over.
snippet: While some progress has been made on the oil spill crisis in the Gulf of Mexico, the restoration is far from over.
lead_paragraph: Is the crisis in the gulf over? In a word, no.

headline.main: Restoring the Gulf
headline.print_headline: Restoring the Gulf

abstract: To receive compensation from BP’s fund, businesses and individuals will likely have to waive their right to sue the company.
snippet: To receive compensation from BP’s fund, businesses and individuals will likely have to waive their right to sue the company.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  People and businesses seeking a lump-sum settlement from BP’s  $20 billion oil spill compensation fund will most likely have to waive their right to sue not only BP, but also all the other major defendants involved with the spill, according to internal documents from the lawyers handling the fund.

headline.main: BP Settlements Likely to Shield Top Defendants
headline.print_headline: BP Settlements Likely to Shield Top Defendants

abstract: University of Georgia researchers take issue with a federal agency’s interpretation of data on the fate of the oil from the Deepwater Horizon spill.
snippet: University of Georgia researchers take issue with a federal agency’s interpretation of data on the fate of the oil from the Deepwater Horizon spill.
lead_paragraph: When the Obama administration released scientific findings early this month estimating that roughly three-quarters of the oil from the BP spill in the Gulf of Mexico had been captured, burned, dispersed, evaporated, degraded or dissolved in the water, a number of independent scientists cried foul, describing the report as premature and suggesting that it was portraying the ecological impact of the spill in an unduly rosy light.

headline.main: Scientists Tussle Over Gulf Oil Tally

abstract: A new federal agency is financing attempts to find a renewable replacement for gasoline and diesel fuel, like a new liquid fuel or a much better battery.
snippet: A new federal agency is financing attempts to find a renewable replacement for gasoline and diesel fuel, like a new liquid fuel or a much better battery.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Most research on renewable energy has focused on replacing the electricity that now comes from burning coal and natural gas. But the spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the reliance on Middle East imports and the threat of global warming are reminders that oil is also a pressing worry. A lot of problems could be solved with a renewable replacement for oil-based gasoline and diesel in the fuel tank  either a new liquid fuel or a much better battery.

headline.main: Finding New Ways to Fill the Tank
headline.print_headline: Finding New Ways to Fill the Tank

abstract: Mr. Hubbard came back to his house in the Lower Ninth Ward of New Orleans, but is having trouble finding work.
snippet: Mr. Hubbard came back to his house in the Lower Ninth Ward of New Orleans, but is having trouble finding work.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS  This was supposed to be the summer Alex Hubbard came back home. After five years of living with his family in a Salvation Army shelter, a hotel room, a FEMA trailer and then a place in Mississippi that belongs to his sister-in-law, he was finally going to move back into his own house in the Lower Ninth Ward.

headline.main: Home Again at Last, but Hit by Another Blow
headline.kicker: Voices From the Spill | Alex Hubbard, Offshore Worker
headline.print_headline: Home Again at Last, but Hit by Another Blow

snippet: Regulators said a trader, eager to make the first trade for oil over $100 a barrel, executed a trade that did not reflect a true price.

headline.print_headline: Ex-ConAgra Unit Settles With U.S. Over Artificial Oil Trade

headline.print_headline: China's Ticking Time Bomb

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration said Monday that it would require significantly more environmental review before approving new offshore drilling permits, ending a practice in which government regulators essentially rubber-stamped potentially hazardous deepwater projects like BP’s out-of-control well.

headline.print_headline: Questions Linger as Shrimp Season Opens in Gulf

headline.main: On Our Radar: Fealty to Kentucky Coal

snippet: The government said Friday that work on a relief well will continue to plug the gusher permanently.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  Although tests of BP’s blown-out well in the Gulf of Mexico appear to show that it is fully sealed, the government said Friday that work on a relief well would continue to complete the job of permanently plugging the gusher.

headline.main: Relief Well to Be Completed in Gulf
headline.print_headline: Relief Well To Proceed To Ensure Spill Is Over

snippet: President Obama on Saturday vowed to maintain an intense government response until the environment is cleaned up and businesses and communities are made whole.
lead_paragraph: PANAMA CITY, Fla.  President Obama on Saturday called the capping of the well that has spewed tens of millions of gallons of oil into the Gulf of Mexico “an important milestone,” but vowed to maintain an intense government response until the environment is cleaned up and businesses and communities are made whole.

headline.main: ‘Our Job Is Not Finished,’ President Tells Gulf Coast
headline.print_headline: ‘Our Job Is Not Finished,’ President Tells Gulf Coast

abstract: Columbus Crew forward Jason Garey, who knows Louisiana’s coastal wetlands well, is doing his part to press for their preservation.
snippet: Columbus Crew forward Jason Garey, who knows Louisiana’s coastal wetlands well, is doing his part to press for their preservation.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in the small southern Louisiana town of Gonzales, Jason Garey did not venture far for family vacations. Many of them were spent down in the marshes, where Garey and his three siblings learned to fish, shrimp and crab in the bountiful brackish waters.

headline.main: Playing for Columbus, but Fighting for the Lands Back Home
headline.print_headline: Playing for Columbus, but Fighting for the Lands Back Home

abstract: BP has agreed to pay a record $50.6 million fine for safety violations found last year at its troubled Texas City refinery.
snippet: BP has agreed to pay a record $50.6 million fine for safety violations found last year at its troubled Texas City refinery.
lead_paragraph: BP has agreed to pay a record $50.6 million fine to the federal government for safety violations found by regulators last year at its troubled refinery in Texas City, Tex., where 15 workers died in a 2005 explosion.

headline.main: BP to Pay Record Fine for Refinery
headline.print_headline: BP to Pay Record Fine For Refinery

abstract: BP owns just a fraction of the U.S. service stations that carry its brand, but independent station owners are suffering since the spill.
snippet: BP owns just a fraction of the U.S. service stations that carry its brand, but independent station owners are suffering since the spill.
lead_paragraph: BP owns fewer than 2 percent of the 10,000 stations across the country that carry its brand, but that did not spare its independent station owners from boycotts, protests, vandalism and customer tirades about fouled beaches and oiled wildlife during the more than three months that crude flowed into the Gulf of Mexico.

headline.main: BP Station Owners Face Long Road to Recovery
headline.print_headline: Like Their Brand, BP Station Owners Face Long Road to Recovery

snippet: Although a “static kill,” or “top kill,” cemented the runaway well last week, the relief well is considered a more reliably permanent solution.
lead_paragraph: The official in charge of the federal response to the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico said Monday that a relief well being drilled was within 30 to 40 feet of intercepting the well that poured millions of barrels of oil in the gulf.

headline.main: Relief Well Nears Point of Intercept
headline.print_headline: Relief Well Nears Point of Intercept

snippet: Once a relief well is completed and successfully intercepting the volatile well, the sealing efforts could be declared a full success.

headline.print_headline: Plug in Gulf Well Is Declared a Success

snippet: At only $100 million, there may even be a scarcity value to Skype’s stock sale.
lead_paragraph: Skype’s initial public offering may add a dose of healthy hype to Silicon Valley. The Internet telephone group’s $100 million float should be red hot. While there have been several tech offerings this year, investor reception has been uneven. A bit of justified excitement over Skype’s growth and its backers’ gains is just what the Valley’s capitalists — and entrepreneurs — need.

headline.main: Skype I.P.O. Could Help Out Silicon Valley
headline.print_headline: Some Exuberance For Skype’s I.P.O.

abstract: The moratorium on deepwater drilling in the Gulf of Mexico, at least for now, must remain in place.
snippet: The moratorium on deepwater drilling in the Gulf of Mexico, at least for now, must remain in place.
lead_paragraph: From the moment he imposed it on May 27, President Obama has been under pressure to lift the six-month moratorium on deepwater drilling in the Gulf of Mexico. Louisiana politicians have argued that the shutdown has done more than the oil spill to cripple the local economy; economists have predicted mass layoffs; and industry has warned of an exodus of rigs to more drilling-friendly parts of the world. The drumbeat has grown louder now that the ruptured well has been plugged.

headline.main: Go Slow on the Moratorium
headline.print_headline: Go Slow on the Moratorium

abstract: Despite persistent underreporting, environmental advocates say that China is becoming somewhat more transparent on environmental matters.
snippet: Despite persistent underreporting, environmental advocates say that China is becoming somewhat more transparent on environmental matters.
lead_paragraph: Not long after taking up work in Beijing, I ran across an interesting chart that, reduced to a nutshell, says this: when Beijing’s air is bad, the government tweaks things to make its pollution reports look better than they really are.

headline.main: A ‘Small’ Spill? China’s Environmental Tango

lead_paragraph: And on the 106th day — after all the top kills and top hats and junk shots — the runaway oil well in the Gulf of Mexico finally seemed close to being tamed. Or was it?

headline.print_headline: Coverage Turns, Cautiously, to Spill Impact

abstract: The oil-hungry bacterium Alcanivorax and fellow microbes are breaking down a significant amount of the oil that gushed into the environment from BP’s runaway well, scientists say.
snippet: The oil-hungry bacterium Alcanivorax and fellow microbes are breaking down a significant amount of the oil that gushed into the environment from BP’s runaway well, scientists say.
lead_paragraph: Among the hidden stars of the gulf cleanup is an oil-hungry bacterium that Dr. Seuss could have named  Alcanivorax. It and fellow microbes are breaking down a significant amount of the oil that gushed into the environment from BP’s runaway well, scientists say. The microbial feasting is known as biodegradation.

headline.print_headline: Oil Spill Cleanup Workers Include Many Very, Very Small Ones

abstract: The cement job was completed earlier than expected, a major step in permanently bringing the well under control.
snippet: The cement job was completed earlier than expected, a major step in permanently bringing the well under control.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  For more than three months, an oil-weary nation has waited for the moment when engineers would begin pumping cement into BP’s runaway well, in hopes of plugging its flow for good.

headline.print_headline: With Little Fanfare, Well Is Plugged With Cement

lead_paragraph: DALIAN, China — Three weeks after a flood of heavy crude oil fouled scores of miles of this immense northern city’s beaches and rocky coastline, a remarkable — some would say heroic — cleanup effort has scrubbed away most traces of the spill.

headline.print_headline: An All-Oil Diet

abstract: Reliance Industries’ $392 million deal with Carrizo Oil and Gas is the latest in a series in which Reliance has been paying top dollar to tap into the American natural gas market.

lead_paragraph: Reliance Industries of India continues to pay top dollar to tap into the natural gas market in the United States, pushing up what some people in the energy industry think are exorbitant prices to obtain unconventional shale gas. Reliance’s $392 million deal with Carrizo Oil and Gas is just one of several shale transactions that are expected by energy bankers.

headline.main: Reliance’s Big Bet on a Pricey Shale Deal

abstract: One of several legislative maneuvers against the oil giant.
snippet: One of several legislative maneuvers against the oil giant.
lead_paragraph: House lawmakers hope to prevent BP from taking a $10 billion tax write-off for its spill response costs. “Claiming billions of dollars in losses from this spill is an affront to the hard-working people of the Gulf Coast who have lost their livelihood,” says a Democratic representative. [The Hill]

headline.main: On Our Radar: Blocking BP’s Write-Off

abstract: The implication of the report, which claimed that most of the oil that leaked into the gulf could be accounted for, was that future damage might be less than had been feared.
snippet: The implication of the report, which claimed that most of the oil that leaked into the gulf could be accounted for, was that future damage might be less than had been feared.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration’s latest report on the Gulf of Mexico disaster set off a war of words Wednesday among scientists, Gulf Coast residents and political pundits about what to make of the Deepwater Horizon spill and its aftermath.

snippet: Attempts to prove that a nation’s continental shelf extends beyond a 200-mile limit for staking mineral rights.

abstract: President Obama is deflecting questions about his effectiveness by turning them into questions about his critics’ coziness with the oil industry.
snippet: President Obama is deflecting questions about his effectiveness by turning them into questions about his critics’ coziness with the oil industry.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  At a political fund-raiser on Thursday for a close friend running for his old Senate seat, President Obama brought up the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico to make his case to voters.

headline.print_headline: Turning a Crisis Into an Opportunity

abstract: Robert Dudley made a crucial protocol stop as he shifts the focus away from plugging the leak in the gulf to selling assets to pay for its cleanup.
snippet: Robert Dudley made a crucial protocol stop as he shifts the focus away from plugging the leak in the gulf to selling assets to pay for its cleanup.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  BP’s next chief executive, Robert Dudley, met with senior Russian officials on Wednesday to discuss the company’s lucrative business here as he began shifting focus from plugging the oil leak in the Gulf of Mexico to selling assets to pay for its cleanup.

headline.main: Next Leader for BP Meets Russian Officials in Moscow
headline.print_headline: Next Leader for BP Meets Russian Officials in Moscow

abstract: Nearly five million barrels of oil have gushed from BP’s well, federal scientists said, announcing the most precise estimates yet of the flow. The number would make this the biggest known oil spill.
snippet: Nearly five million barrels of oil have gushed from BP’s well, federal scientists said, announcing the most precise estimates yet of the flow. The number would make this the biggest known oil spill.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Nearly five million barrels of oil have gushed from the BP’s well since the Deepwater Horizon spill began on April 20, federal scientists said on Monday in announcing the most precise estimates yet of the well’s flow rate. The estimates would make this spill far bigger than the 3.3 million barrels spilled by the Mexican rig Ixtoc I in 1979, previously believed to be the world’s largest accidental release of oil.

headline.main: U.S. Puts Oil Spill Total at Nearly 5 Million Barrels
headline.print_headline: U.S. Puts Oil Spill Total at Nearly 5 Million Barrels

abstract: Confidential reports by Transocean, the owner of the Deepwater Horizon rig, offer an unusually candid view of safety and maintenance concerns.
snippet: Confidential reports by Transocean, the owner of the Deepwater Horizon rig, offer an unusually candid view of safety and maintenance concerns.
lead_paragraph: The company that owned the oil rig that exploded in the Gulf of Mexico in April had widespread safety concerns about several of its other rigs in the gulf, and a month before the disaster it commissioned a broad review of the safety culture of the company’s North American operations, according to confidential internal reports.

headline.main: Oil Rig’s Owner Had Safety Issue at Three Other Wells
headline.print_headline: OIL RIG’S OWNER HAD SAFETY ISSUE AT 3 OTHER WELLS

abstract: BP said that pumping heavy drilling mud into its stricken well in the Gulf seemed to stabilize pressure.
snippet: BP said that pumping heavy drilling mud into its stricken well in the Gulf seemed to stabilize pressure.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — An operation that pumped heavy drilling mud to plug BP’s runaway oil well in the Gulf of Mexico has been so successful that Obama administration officials said on Wednesday they were convinced the well would never leak again.

headline.print_headline:
‘Static Kill’
Of the Well
Is Working,

abstract: The slow fouling of Newtown Creek lacks the drama of the gulf spill, but its impact has been profound. Advocates are hoping for Superfund designation.
snippet: The slow fouling of Newtown Creek lacks the drama of the gulf spill, but its impact has been profound. Advocates are hoping for Superfund designation.
lead_paragraph: The salt marshes are long gone from Newtown Creek, and so are most of the birds and fish. Now, this waterway straddling Brooklyn and Queens is dotted by bulkheads and containment booms meant to keep oil away from the shoreline while underground pumps work around the clock removing petroleum from adjacent land.

headline.main: Between Queens and Brooklyn, an Oil Spill’s Legacy
headline.print_headline: Where Brooklyn And Queens Meet, A Quiet Parallel To the Gulf Spill

abstract: If you thought petroleum came from dinosaurs, think again, and much smaller.
snippet: If you thought petroleum came from dinosaurs, think again, and much smaller.
lead_paragraph: In 1913, as the automobile zoomed into American life, The Outing Magazine gave its readers a bit of background on what fueled the new motorcars in “The Story of Gasoline.” After a brief vignette describing the death of “old Colonel Stegosaurus Ungulatus,” the article explained that “yesterday you poured the remains of the dinosaur from a measuring-can — which, let us hope, held five gallons, full measure — into your gasoline tank.”

headline.main: Tracing Oil Reserves to Their Tiny Origins
headline.print_headline: Tracing Oil Reserves to Their Tiny Origins

abstract: Only about 26 percent of the oil from the gulf leak is still onshore or in the water, and most of it is breaking down rapidly, officials say.
snippet: Only about 26 percent of the oil from the gulf leak is still onshore or in the water, and most of it is breaking down rapidly, officials say.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The government is expected to announce on Wednesday that three-quarters of the oil from the Deepwater Horizon leak has already evaporated, dispersed, been captured or otherwise eliminated — and that much of the rest is so diluted that it does not seem to pose much additional risk of harm.

headline.main: U.S. Finds Most Oil From Spill Poses Little Additional Risk

abstract: A former prosecutor acknowledges that his background could be “disorienting and maybe a little scary” to employees of the former Minerals Management Service.

lead_paragraph: The head of the new federal agency for regulating offshore drilling would like to lift the moratorium on deep-water offshore drilling as soon as the agency is “comfortable” that enough safety improvements are in place, he told reporters on Tuesday. abstract: Trying to offset the effect of sanctions, Iran said Wednesday that it would increase gasoline production by converting two petrochemical plants so they could produce gasoline.
snippet: Trying to offset the effect of sanctions, Iran said Wednesday that it would increase gasoline production by converting two petrochemical plants so they could produce gasoline.
lead_paragraph: Trying to offset the effect of sanctions on the country’s nuclear program, Iran said Wednesday that it would increase domestic gasoline production by converting two petrochemical plants so they could produce gasoline by processing benzene. Iran is the world’s fifth-largest exporter of crude oil, but a lack of refining capacity forces it to import about 30 percent of its gasoline. The plan to increase production was announced by the oil minister, Masoud Mirkazemi, who predicted that Iran would become a net exporter of gasoline by 2015. Benzene, a product derived from natural gas, can be further processed to produce gasoline for use in cars and other vehicles. Experts said, however, that the product would burn poorly and contain more impurities than regular gasoline, causing damage to engines.

headline.main: Iran: Plants to Use Benzene to Increase Gas Production
headline.print_headline: Iran: Plants To Use Benzene To Increase Gas Production

abstract: Robert Dudley, an American, will take over leadership of the company after repeated stumbles by Tony Hayward in responding to the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.
snippet: Robert Dudley, an American, will take over leadership of the company after repeated stumbles by Tony Hayward in responding to the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.
lead_paragraph: BP’s board is expected on Monday to name an American, Robert Dudley, as its chief executive, replacing Tony Hayward, whose repeated stumbles during the company’s three-month oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico alienated federal and state officials as well as residents of the Gulf Coast.

lead_paragraph: Interior Secretary Ken Salazar announced last week that he will open 1.8 million acres of the National Petroleum Reserve in northern Alaska to oil and gas leasing. He pledged to protect habitat for migratory birds and caribou near Teshekpuk Lake, an ecologically sensitive area inside the 1.8 million acre tract  welcome news. lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS  BP said Thursday that it had capped its hemorrhaging well, at least temporarily, marking the first time in 86 days that oil was not gushing into the Gulf of Mexico.

abstract: Steven Chu has no training in geology or oil well technology, but he has been a quick study and is now President Obama’s go-to man on the gulf oil spill.
snippet: Steven Chu has no training in geology or oil well technology, but he has been a quick study and is now President Obama’s go-to man on the gulf oil spill.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Energy Secretary Steven Chu may hold a Nobel Prize in physics, but he has no training in geology, seismology or oil well technology. Nevertheless, he has stepped in repeatedly to take command of the effort to contain BP’s runaway well, often ordering company officials to take steps they might not have taken on their own.

Feinberg, hopping in and out a Learjet, a helicopter and several S.U.V.s, took his gift for oratory to four towns in southern Louisiana on Thursday to make his pitch to locals: The $20 billion fund from BP to compensate those harmed by the Gulf of Mexico oil spill, and they should get their share.

lead_paragraph: Despite legal challenges from industry, complaints from local politicians and bad rulings from unsympathetic judges, the Obama administration has rightly chosen to reaffirm its decision in May to suspend deep-water drilling activities in the Gulf of Mexico. On Monday, Interior Secretary Ken Salazar issued a second moratorium to replace an earlier ban that was tossed out in federal court. It is as strong as the first ban and, if anything, more tightly argued.

abstract: A history of weathering storms, and disasters, on the gulf’s Bayou Lafourche.
snippet: A history of weathering storms, and disasters, on the gulf’s Bayou Lafourche.
lead_paragraph: I WAS born and raised on Bayou Lafourche, 30 miles from Grand Isle, which is Louisiana’s only inhabited barrier island and also the setting of Kate Chopin’s 19th-century novel of maternal disorientation, “The Awakening.” But “Frankenstein” offers the more appropriate narrative lesson for the Deepwater Horizon disaster. Mary Shelley begins her story with the anti-hero Victor Frankenstein declaring his admiration for scientists who “penetrate into the recesses of nature.” Full of hubris, he “pursued nature to her hiding places,” bringing horror upon his family and community. He has no foresight, only the belief that “maternal nature” can be manipulated by unvetted technology.

headline.main: Our Life, Between Sea and Oil

lead_paragraph: Florida has begun a national advertising campaign to protect its fun-in-the-sun image from the sludge and stink of the oil spill  spending almost as much in June (about $9.5 million) as the state usually spends in a year. State officials describe it as a necessity: tourism is Florida’s largest industry, employing one million people and bringing in $60 billion a year. The goal, they say, is to show off what the state still has to offer.

lead_paragraph: AMERICA’S addiction to oil is making itself felt on the blackened wings of pelicans in the Gulf of Mexico. lead_paragraph: PRESIDENT Obama is not known for wild pronouncements, so it was startling to hear him liken the gulf oil spill to 9/11. Alas, this bold analogy, made in an interview with Roger Simon of Politico, proved a misleading trailer for the main event. In the president’s prime-time address a few days later, there was still talk of war, but the ammunition was sanded down to bullet points: “a clean energy future,” “a long-term gulf coast restoration plan” and, that most dreaded of perennials, “a national commission.” Such generic placeholders, unanimated by details or deadlines, are Washingtonese for “The buck stops elsewhere.”

David Petraeus  who is not God, although certain members of Congress have been known to worship at his altar  semifainted at a Senate Armed Services Committee hearing.

lead_paragraph: A specially outfitted ship ventures into deep ocean waters in search of oil, increasingly difficult to find. Lines of authority aboard the ship become tangled. Ambition outstrips ability. The unpredictable forces of nature rear up, and death and destruction follow in their wake. “Some fell flat on their faces,” an eyewitness reported of the stricken crew. “Through the breach, they heard the waters pour.”

lead_paragraph: Hamper oil drilling and motorists will pay, industry groupies warn. But the drop in crude prices since BP’s Gulf of Mexico blowup suggests deepwater wells have a picayune impact on the market for oil. It’s a reminder that America relies on imports anyway and it won’t make any real difference to ban difficult drilling until oil companies prove it is safe.

abstract: It makes sense that the BP disaster would weigh more heavily than the Greek debt crisis on stocks: it lays bare the limits of human capability.

lead_paragraph: Forget Greece. The biggest blow to global investor confidence right now lies 5,000 feet below the waters of the Gulf of Mexico. That may sound odd. At worst, the disaster at the Macondo well would wipe out one big company, BP; a sovereign default, on the other hand, could domino throughout stock, bond and currency markets, bringing down some of the Continent’s biggest banks and potentially breaking up the single currency.

abstract: For Father’s Day, a father and son debate moral resolve and the challenge of change.
snippet: For Father’s Day, a father and son debate moral resolve and the challenge of change.
lead_paragraph: DANIEL Had I been 18 in November 2008, I would have voted for Barack Obama. However, being 14, I settled for voicing my support for him and expressing joy at his election. I believed, innocently, that his administration would put its foot down, stamping out the environmental crisis that his predecessors had allowed to fester unnoticed. I felt Mr. Obama knew how to do the right thing morally, even if it meant going against the “right thing” politically.

abstract: Is our inability to control ourselves the defining feature of our time?
snippet: Is our inability to control ourselves the defining feature of our time?
lead_paragraph: The gulf oil fiasco is just the latest instance in which a lack of regulation — or dysfunctional system of regulation — has led to a major American disaster. After the failure of the levees during Hurricane Katrina, the Wall Street meltdown of 2008, the collapse of the housing market and now the BP spill,we have come to what feels like a moment of reckoning, with some tentative signs that our country’s decades-long love affair with deregulation is starting to chill.

Chrysler was forced into a merger. At the banks that received government bailouts, executive pay was curbed; at insurance companies seeking to jack up premiums, scathing criticism led to rollbacks.

lead_paragraph: You’re a veteran of the Iraq war and a former Navy submarine officer who’s now a scholar of nuclear policy at Columbia University. abstract: Whether the problem is financial or environmental, three ingredients can add up to a crisis, Richard H. Thaler says.
snippet: Whether the problem is financial or environmental, three ingredients can add up to a crisis, Richard H. Thaler says.
lead_paragraph: AS the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico follows on the heels of the financial crisis, we can discern a toxic recipe for catastrophe. The ingredients include risks that are erroneously thought to be vanishingly small, complex technology that isn’t fully grasped by either top management or regulators, and tricky relationships among companies that are not sure how much they can count on their partners.

lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS  Delicately manipulating a 20-foot-long shear at depths of nearly a mile, technicians successfully snipped a key riser pipe on Thursday in their effort to contain the oil spewing into the Gulf of Mexico from a stricken undersea well. Mr. Obama’s administration, too, had been breached, and the accumulating cloud threatened to obscure its considerable achievements — particularly the comprehensive reforms of health care and federal education spending — as the president heads toward the halfway point in his term.

abstract: What the oil spill and the financial crisis have in common.
snippet: What the oil spill and the financial crisis have in common.
lead_paragraph: In retrospect, the pattern seems clear. Years before the Deepwater Horizon rig blew, BP was developing a reputation as an oil company that took safety risks to save money. An explosion at a Texas refinery killed 15 workers in 2005, and federal regulators and a panel led by James A. Baker III, the former secretary of state, said that cost cutting was partly to blame. The next year, a corroded pipeline in Alaska poured oil into Prudhoe Bay. None other than Joe Barton, a Republican congressman from Texas and a global-warming skeptic, upbraided BP managers for their “seeming indifference to safety and environmental issues.”

headline.main: Spillonomics: Underestimating Risk
headline.print_headline: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW; Underestimating Risk

lead_paragraph: FOR Barack Obama’s knee-jerk foes, of course it was his Katrina. But for the rest of us, there’s the nagging fear that the largest oil spill in our history could yet prove worse if it drags on much longer. It might not only wreck the ecology of a region but capsize the principal mission of the Obama presidency.

headline.main: Obama’s Katrina? Maybe Worse

Nonetheless, the company still insists that an accurate measurement of the spill rate is neither necessary, as it would do nothing to alter their response efforts, nor is it possible with existing science.

lead_paragraph: An explosion and fire on a drilling rig on April 20 left 11 workers missing and presumed dead. The rig sank two days later about 50 miles off the Louisiana coast. Since then, attempts to shut off the flow of oil streaming into the Gulf of Mexico have been unsuccessful and the search continues for a cause and for ways to prevent such blowouts in the future. Questions persist about who will be liable for damage from the spill and the risks to local wildlife. Following is an updated oil spill primer. A previous Q. and A. can be found at nytimes.com/national.

headline.main: The Price and Who Pays: Updates From the Gulf

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration greatly expanded the fishing ban in the Gulf of Mexico on Tuesday in response to spreading oil from the BP well blowout. The prohibited area now covers 19 percent of the gulf, nearly double what it was, according to the agency.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal regulators responsible for oversight of drilling in the Gulf of Mexico allowed industry officials several years ago to fill in their own inspection reports in pencil — and then turned them over to the regulators, who traced over them in pen before submitting the reports to the agency, according to an inspector general’s report to be released this week. The report said that investigators "could not discern if any fraudulent alterations were present on these forms."

Khodorkovsky, sat in a glass cage in a dingy, third-floor courtroom and listened while prosecutors sought to prolong his time behind bars by charging that he embezzled billions of dollars worth of oil. abstract: After the oil spill in the gulf, an energy/climate/jobs bill is needed more than ever. America has to stop messing around with the environment’s future.

lead_paragraph: The Environmental Protection Agency has said it will rule by the end of this month on whether to allow gasoline retailers to sell a mixture that is 15 percent ethanol and 85 percent unleaded regular, a change from the current maximum of 10 percent ethanol. Coalitions have lined up — on one side, the corn farmers and ethanol producers, and on the other, the oil refiners, auto companies, manufacturers of gasoline-powered equipment and companies that use corn to raise livestock.

headline.main: Salvos Fly as Ethanol Ruling Nears

lead_paragraph: Schlumberger’s shareholders have been in a state since news leaked last week of the company’s bid for Smith International, its rival in the oilfield services sector. Skeptical investors have since stripped more than $5 billion from the value of Schlumberger, the industry leader, a powerful slap in the face of its chief, Andrew F. Gould. Such punishment appears excessive.

headline.main: Excess Skepticism on Schlumberger?

abstract: An oil rig explosion shreds a company’s crafted green image.

What is interesting about Graham is that he has been willing  courageously in my view  to depart from the prevailing G.O.P. consensus that the only energy policy we need is “drill, baby, drill.”

abstract: A reader responds.
snippet: A reader responds.
lead_paragraph: Christopher J. Brownfield should speak a little more carefully when discussing the idea of using nuclear weapons to stop the BP leak.Brownfield states that the “Russians did it four times with 100-percent success rate.” The Russians did not destroy oil wells in this way. Rather, they used nuclear explosives to seal runaway gas wells, but never an oil well on land or underwater. Brownfield also never mentions how difficult it would be to emplace a nuclear explosive a mile underwater, set it off and be assured that no other catastrophe would result.

abstract: Not one British person desires anything other than as fast a resolution as possible, with BP, Transocean and Halliburton footing the bill for the clean up.
snippet: Not one British person desires anything other than as fast a resolution as possible, with BP, Transocean and Halliburton footing the bill for the clean up.
lead_paragraph: Regarding “B(ritish) P(ique)” by Timothy Egan (Views, June 15): The crisis in the Gulf of Mexico is indeed a long term problem for the whole region. I would also add that not one British person desires anything other than as fast a resolution as possible, with BP, Transocean and Halliburton footing the bill for the clean up.

abstract: "The oil spills we don't hear about" (Views, June 5-6) affirms two things - that the world is in an environmental slump, and that less-developed countries simply do not have the political will or institutional means to introduce measures to curb ecological self-destruction.
snippet: "The oil spills we don't hear about" (Views, June 5-6) affirms two things - that the world is in an environmental slump, and that less-developed countries simply do not have the political will or institutional means to introduce measures to curb e...
lead_paragraph: “The oil spills we don’t hear about” (Views, June 5-6) affirms two things — that the world is in an environmental slump, and that less-developed countries simply do not have the political will or institutional means to introduce measures to curb ecological self-destruction. In particular, Nigeria’s over-reliance on the petroleum industry for economic growth — which is resulting in the loss of biodiversity and unsustainable development — has had terrible ramifications on living conditions.

abstract: Regarding the news article "Nuke the oil leak? U.S. says it's crazy and won't work" (June 4): The public has been brought up on the fiction that life is risk-free, a phenomenon which is again confirmed by the general reaction to the disastrous oil leak in the Gulf of Mexico.
snippet: Regarding the news article "Nuke the oil leak? U.S. says it's crazy and won't work" (June 4): The public has been brought up on the fiction that life is risk-free, a phenomenon which is again confirmed by the general reaction to the disastrous oil...
lead_paragraph: Regarding the news article “Nuke the oil leak? U.S. says it’s crazy and won’t work” (June 4): There is a lesson to be learned if the American public were in the mood to learn it. The public has been brought up on the fiction that life is risk-free, a phenomenon which is again confirmed by the general reaction to the disastrous oil leak in the Gulf of Mexico.

abstract: Regarding "Drilling for certainty" (Views, May 29-30): David Brooks is correct about the risks entailed in building and operating complex systems such as those involved in the Deepwater Horizon oil drilling operation (and, as he points out, in many other areas of modern life as well). In particular, he's right about the danger that, precisely because such systems are so complicated, they may contain hidden flaws which may lead to catastrophic consequences.

abstract: Conventional wisdom suggests that oil companies can do no good for the people of Burma and their notoriously misruled country. This view is founded on years of forced labor, killings and other abuses by the Burmese military in connection to gas pipelines in the country, and to the billions of dollars the sector has generated for the unpopular ruling junta.
